Class GameGrid

                  ch.aplu.android.GameGrid
All Implemented Interfaces:
android.content.ComponentCallbacks, android.media.MediaPlayer.OnCompletionListener, android.view.KeyEvent.Callback, android.view.LayoutInflater.Factory, android.view.View.OnCreateContextMenuListener, android.view.Window.Callback, GGActListener
Direct Known Subclasses:
CardGame, TurtlePane
public class GameGrid
extends android.app.Activity
implements GGActListener, android.media.MediaPlayer.OnCompletionListener

Class to create a container where the actors live in. It is a two dimensional grid of cells. The size of cells can be specified (in pixel units = distance between two adjacent pixels) at GrameGrid's creation time, and is constant after creation. Simple scenarios may use large cells that entirely contain the representations of objects in a single cell. More elaborate scenarios may use smaller cells (down to a single pixel unit) to achieve fine-grained placement and smoother animation. The background of the game grid can be decorated with drawings or a background image.

The cellSize is given in pixel units, e.g. the distance between adjacent pixels. The size in pixel units of the usable playground is width = nbHorzCells * cellSize horizontally and height = nbVertCells * cellSize vertically. Thus the playground contains nbHorzPixels = width + 1 pixels horizontally and nbVertPixels = height + 1 pixels vertically, with pixel indexes 0 <= i <= width (inclusive), 0 <= k <= height (inclusive) respectively.

For pixel accurate positioning be aware that an image that has the size m x n in pixel units contains m+1 pixels horizontally and n+1 pixels vertically. So the background image must have nbVertPixels horizontally and nbVerticalPixels vertically to fit exactly into the playground. (E.g. GameGrid(30, 20, 10) will need a background image with 301 x 201 pixels.)

To increase performance the automatic repainting of the graphics canvas is disabled. Repainting is done in every simulation cycle, when the window is moved or by calling refresh(). The x- and y-coordinates for positioning actors are actually the cell index ranging from 0 <= x < nbHorzCells (exclusive) horizontally and 0 <= y < nbVertCells (exclusive) vertically. There image is automatically centered in the cell as accurate as possible.

The class design is inspired by the great Greenfoot programming environment (see www.greenfoot.org) and by an article about game programming in Java at www.cokeandcode.com/tutorials with thanks to the authors. The code is entirely rewritten and in my responsability.

Methods that access/modify the internal data structure are made thread-safe. This does not mean that ALL methods are thread-safe.

The platform call of onCreate() will create a separate thread (called "main-thread") that calls main(). The application class should be derived from GameGrid and override main(), where all operations should take place. To start the simulation thread that calls act() periodically, either click the Run (MENU) button or call doRun() in the main() method.

If the device orientation is not fixed and the orientation changes (the device is flipped or rotated), the simulation thread stops and a cleanup is performed where all actors are removed from the game grid It is assumed that the main method has finished at that time, because a new main thread is started that invokes the main() method again. This design strategy ensures that the game is restarted automatically when the device is flipped. If the game should continue when the device is flipped, the automatic cleanup can be disabled by calling setCleanup(false) in the GameGrid constructor. This does not prevent the creation of a new main thread. It is up to the developer to handle all actions properly when main() is invoked again. The default behaviour is ScreenOrientation.FIXED that will maintain the device orientation found when the application starts.

To prevent memory leaks and hanging applications when the main thread does not return, onPause() shuts down the Dalvik virtual machine by killing the process in the onPause() notification. When an external telephone call arrives, onPause() is invoked and the virtual machine is stopped too. You may override onPause() and call superOnPause() or by calling enableKill(false) to prevent termination, but do not call refresh() while pausing.

Keep in mind that before main() runs, the environment is not fully initialized. Therefore do not create visible GUI elements as instance variables or in the application class constructor. If needed you may declare instance reference with no initialization and create the objects in main(). It is permitted to run an endless loop in main() because the virtual machine will kill the main thread when exiting.

If an exception is thrown in main() or act() the stack trace is reported as Logcat info (with tag "ch.aplu.android").

When the device is rotated from landscape to portrait or vice versa, the game state is reinitialized but the current simulation period is maintained (like pressing the reset() key or calling doReset().

The standard smartphone's buttons MENU, BACK and VOLUME_UP, VOLUME_DOWN may be used for the game grid navigation. If calling the constructor with the isNavigation flat set to true the following actions are enabled:
- After application start or reset, click MENU: doRun()
- When running, click MENU: doPause()
- If paused, click MENU: doStep()
- If paused, long press MENU: doRun()
- Click HOME: doReset()
- Click VOLUME_UP: decrease simulation period by 10 (increasing speed)
- Click VOLUME_DOWN: increase simulation period by 10 (decreasing speed)

To exit the application, use the HOME button. This will kill the running process. When the navigation is not enabled, the BACK button will also kill the procethe process and the MENU button is inactive. You may register a navigation listener to get notifications of the button actions, the normal action are disable.

We provide an auto zoom feature by using the CellZoom and WindowZoom parameters in the GameGrid constructor. If enabled, all images are automatically zoomed by a zoom factor calculated from the current screen size. Collision and touch areas are displaced and zoomed accordingly. The zoom factor may also be set by setZoomFactor(). A zoom factor of 1 will disable auto zoom.

Guidelines for using auto zoom:

Grid based games:
- Assume a fixed size game, e.g. 10x10 grid with cell size 50
- Create actor pictures with image sizes that fit well into cells of size 50
- Create background image with size 501x501
- Use GameGrid constructor with cellZoom(50)
- If you need runtime screen coordinates (e.g. for Actor.setLocationOffset()). use getCellSize() to get the current cell size. Never use magic numbers that assume a fixed grid size
- Set the touch area parameters based on this window layout. (They are automatically adapted at runtime).

Pixel based games:
- Assume a fixed size game, e.g. 500x500 pixels
- Create actor pictures with image sizes that fit well into this window
- Create background image with size 501x501 pixels
- Use GameGrid constructor with windowZoom(500)
- If you need runtime screen coordinates, use getNbHorzCells() and getNbVertCells() to get the current window size. Never use magic numbers that assume a fixed window size
- If you use full screen windows, the zoom factor is adapted to the smaller side of the window rectangle. The aspect ratio is approximately 16:9. To get the exact virtual size of the playground, use getVirtualPgWidth() and getVirtualPgHeight() (one of them is 500, which one depends on the device orientation)
- Set the touch and collision area parameters based on this window layout. (They are automatically adapted at runtime).

Constant for setScreenOrientation(). Maintains fixed portrait orientation.

KILLPROCESS

Constant for setScreenOrientation(). Process will be killed when orientation changes.

RESTART

public static final GGNavigationListener.ScreenOrientation RESTART
Constant for setScreenOrientation(). All actors are removed from the game grid and the main() method is invoked again (default option).

REPORT

public static final GGNavigationListener.ScreenOrientation REPORT
Constant for setScreenOrientation(). The initializaton process is abandoned, but a registered GGOrientationListener is notified.

Public access to the GameGrid instance.

Constructor Detail

GameGrid

public GameGrid()
Same as GameGrid(boolean isFullScreen, WindowZoom windowZoom) with isFullScreen = false and windowZoom = null, so the graphics window is a square and images are not zoomed.

GameGrid

public GameGrid(GameGrid.WindowZoom windowZoom)
Same as GameGrid(boolean isFullScreen, WindowZoom windowZoom) with isFullScreen = false, so the graphics window is a square. All loaded images are automatically zoomed.

Parameters:
windowZoom - a WindowZoom reference to define the zoom factor. Use windowZoom(int windowSize) to create it; if null, the images are not zoomed

GameGrid

public GameGrid(boolean isFullScreen,
                GameGrid.WindowZoom windowZoom)
Constructs a game activity with no active navigation buttons, no visible grid (transparent) and no background image. The cellSize is 1 pixel and the number of horizontal and vertical cells are equal and adapted to fit the current display. windowZoom is used to adapt automatically the size of all loaded images to the current window size. Call getNbHorzCells() and getNbVertCells() to know the current window size. The navigation is disabled.

Parameters:
isFullScreen - if true, the windows is the maximum rectangle that fits the screen; otherwise it is the maximum square that fits the screen
windowZoom - a WindowZoom reference to define the zoom factor. Use windowZoom(int windowSize) to create it; if null, the images are not zoomed

GameGrid

public GameGrid(int borderColor)
Same as GameGrid(int borderColor, booolean isNavigation, boolean isFullscreen, WindowZoom windowZoom) with isNavigation = false, isFullScreen = false and windowZoom = null, so the graphics window is a square and images are not zoomed.

Parameters:
borderColor - the color of the border

GameGrid

public GameGrid(int borderColor,
                GameGrid.WindowZoom windowZoom)
Same as GameGrid(int borderColor, boolean isNavigation, boolean isFullscreen, WindowZoom windowZoom) with isNavigation = false and isFullScreen = false, so the graphics window is a square.

Parameters:
borderColor - the color of the border
windowZoom - a WindowZoom reference to define the zoom factor. Use windowZoom(int windowSize) to create it; if null, the images are not zoomed

GameGrid

public GameGrid(int borderColor,
                boolean isNavigation,
                boolean isFullScreen,
                GameGrid.WindowZoom windowZoom)
Constructs a game activity with no active navigation buttons, no visible grid (transparent) and no background image. The cellSize is 1 pixel and the number of horizontal and vertical cells are equals and adapted to fit the current display. windowZoom is used to adapt automatically the size of all loaded images to the current window size. Call getNbHorzCells() and getNbVertCells() to know the current window size. The graphics window is surrounded by a border with given color.

Parameters:
borderColor - the color of the border
isFullScreen - if true, the windows is the maximum rectangle that fits the screen; otherwise it is the maximum square that fits the screen
windowZoom - a WindowZoom reference to define the zoom factor. Use windowZoom(int windowSize) to create it; if null, the images are not zoomed

GameGrid

Same as GameGrid(String bgImagePath, boolean isNavigation, boolean isFullScreen, WindowZoom windowZoom) with isNavigation = false, isFullScreen = false and windowZoom = null, so the graphics window is a square and images are not zoomed

Parameters:
bgImagePath - the path to a background image (if null, no background image)

GameGrid

public GameGrid(java.lang.String bgImagePath,
                GameGrid.WindowZoom windowZoom)
Same as GameGrid(String bgImagePath, boolean isNavigation, boolean isFullScreen, WindowZoom windowZoom) with isNavigation = false, isFullScreen = false, so the graphics window is a square.

Parameters:
bgImagePath - the path to a background image (if null, no background image)
windowZoom - a WindowZoom reference to define the zoom factor. Use windowZoom(int windowSize) to create it; if null, the images are not zoomed

GameGrid

public GameGrid(java.lang.String bgImagePath,
                boolean isNavigation,
                boolean isFullScreen,
                GameGrid.WindowZoom windowZoom)
Constructs a game activity with no visible grid (transparent) possibly a background image and possibly active navitation buttons. The cellSize is 1 pixel and the number of horizontal and vertical cells are equals and adapted to fit the current display. windowZoom is used to adapt automatically the size of all loaded images to the current window size. Call getNbHorzCells() and getNbVertCells() to know the current window size.
From the given image path of the background the file in searched in the following order:
- filename contains a colon : searched at URL in format http://...
- filename contains slash or backslash : search on sdcard ("/sdcard/" appended)
- otherwise if contains no dot, searched in app package, else search on sdcard
e.g. if neither a dot nor a slash, searched from res/drawable resource folder

Parameters:
bgImagePath - the path to a background image (if null, no background image)
isNavigation - if true, the standard smartphone's buttons are active for navigation
isFullScreen - if true, the windows is the maximum rectangle that fits the screen; otherwise it is the maximum square that fits the screen
windowZoom - a WindowZoom reference to define the zoom factor. Use windowZoom(int windowSize) to create it; if null, the images are not zoomed

GameGrid

public GameGrid(int nbHorzCells,
                int nbVertCells,
                int cellSize)
Constructs a game activity with no active navigation buttons, no visible grid (transparent) and no background image. The cellSize is given in pixel units, e.g. the distance between adjacent pixels. The images are not zoomed when loaded.

Parameters:
nbHorzCells - the number of horizontal cells
nbVertCells - the number of vertical cells
cellSize - the requested cell size in pixels, if >0 the cell size is fixed even if the game grid does not fit the screen, if 0 the size is adjusted to fit the screen, changing when the screen is turned. The cell size can be requested by calling getCellSize()

GameGrid

public GameGrid(int nbHorzCells,
                int nbVertCells,
                GameGrid.CellZoom cellZoom)
Same as GameGrid(int nbHorzCells, int nbVertCells, int cellSize), but the grid size is adapted to fit the current screen and images are zoomed automatically when loaded.

Parameters:
nbHorzCells - the number of horizontal cells
nbVertCells - the number of vertical cells
cellZoom - a CellZoom reference to define the zoom factor. Use cellZoom(int cellSize) to create it; if null, the images are not zoomed

GameGrid

public GameGrid(int nbHorzCells,
                int nbVertCells,
                int cellSize,
                int gridColor)
Constructs a game activity with no active navigation buttons and possibly a visible grid, but no background image. The cellSize is given in pixel units, e.g. the distance between adjacent pixels. The images are not zoomed when loaded.

Parameters:
nbHorzCells - the number of horizontal cells
nbVertCells - the number of vertical cells
cellSize - the requested cell size in pixels, if >0 the cell size is fixed even if the game grid does not fit the screen, if 0 the size is adjusted to fit the screen, changing when the screen is turned. The cell size can be requested by calling getCellSize()
gridColor - the color of the grid (if Color.TRANSPARENT, no grid is shown)

nbVertCells - the number of vertical cells
cellZoom - a CellZoom reference to define the zoom factor. Use cellZoom(int cellSize) to create it; if null, the images are not zoomed
gridColor - the color of the grid (if Color.TRANSPARENT, no grid is shown)

nbVertCells - the number of vertical cells

gridColor - the color of the grid (if Color.TRANSPARENT, no grid is shown)

GameGrid

public GameGrid(int nbHorzCells,
                int nbVertCells,
                int cellSize,
                int gridColor,
                java.lang.String bgImagePath,
                boolean isNavigation)
Constructs a game activity with possibly active navigation buttons, possibly a visible grid and possibly a background image. The cellSize is given in pixel units, e.g. the distance between adjacent pixels. From the given image path of the background the file in searched in the following order:
- filename contains a colon : searched at URL in format http://...
- filename contains slash or backslash : search on sdcard ("/sdcard/" appended)
- otherwise if contains no dot, searched in app package, else search on sdcard
e.g. if neither a dot nor a slash, searched from res/drawable resource folder.
The images are not zoomed when loaded.

Parameters:
nbHorzCells - the number of horizontal cells
nbVertCells - the number of vertical cells
cellSize - the requested cell size in pixels, if >0 the cell size is fixed even if the game grid does not fit the screen, if 0 the size is adjusted to fit the screen, changing when the screen is turned. The cell size can be requested by calling getCellSize()
gridColor - the color of the grid (if Color.TRANSPARENT, no grid is shown)
bgImagePath - the path to a background image (if null, no background image)
isNavigation - if true, the standard smartphone's buttons are active for navigation

GameGrid

public GameGrid(int nbHorzCells,
                int nbVertCells,
                GameGrid.CellZoom cellZoom,
                int gridColor,
                java.lang.String bgImagePath,
                boolean isNavigation)

Parameters:
nbHorzCells - the number of horizontal cells
nbVertCells - the number of vertical cells
cellZoom - a CellZoom reference to define the zoom factor. Use cellZoom(int cellSize) to create it; if null, the images are not zoomed
gridColor - the color of the grid (if Color.TRANSPARENT, no grid is shown)
bgImagePath - the path to a background image (if null, no background image)
isNavigation - if true, the standard smartphone's buttons are active for navigation

setRefreshEnabled

public void setRefreshEnabled(boolean enabled)
Enables/disables the automatic repainting of the graphics in every simulation cycle. If disabled, the graphics is freezed until refresh() is called. Keep in mind that there is no automatic refresh if the simulation cycling is not turned on either by calling doRun() or clicking the Run button.

Parameters:
enabled - if true, the automatic refresh is enabled; otherwise disabled.

isRefreshEnabled

public boolean isRefreshEnabled()
Checks if the automatic refresh in every simulation cycle is enabled.

Returns:
true, if refresh is enabled; false, if disabled

refresh

public void refresh()
Repaints the graphics to show any changes in the offscreen buffer. This method is automatically called in every simulation cycle (if not turned off by setRefreshEnabled(false)). Rapidly repeated refreshing by your own code may cause the graphics to flicker.

getPanel

public GGPanel getPanel()
Sets the float user coordinate system of the GGPanel to (xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax) = (0, 1, 0, 1) and returns a reference to the GGPanel.

Returns:
a reference to the GGPanel

                        float xmax,

a reference to the GGPanel

notifyCreate

public void notifyCreate()
Empty method called last in onCreate(). Override to add user specific code needed to be executed when onCreate() is invoked. Be aware that the main thread is not yet started at this moment.

requestBluetoothEnable

public void requestBluetoothEnable()
Shows a modal dialog to request the user to enable Bluetooth. Blocks until the user replies. Don't call it after GGConsole.init(). Check the answer using BluetoothAdapter.isEnabled().

requestBluetoothDiscoverability

public int requestBluetoothDiscoverability(int duration)
Shows a modal dialog to request the user to set the device discovarable for the given amount of time. If Bluetooth is disabled, it is enabled now. Blocks until the user replies. Don't call it after GGConsole.init().

Parameters:
duration - the new duration for discoverablity in seconds (0..300 s). 0 will set the default duration of 120 s.
Returns:
the duration for discoverability, 0 if user rejects the setting

addSoftButton

public void addSoftButton(int buttonId,
                          java.lang.String label)
Adds a soft button with given Id and button label at the bottom of the view. The label text length should not exceed 4. This method must be called before the buttons are shown (typically in the application class constructor).

Parameters:
buttonId - the number of the button (0..3), 0 is the most left button, 3 the most right button
label - the text shown on the button (max 4 chars)

setSoftButtonVisible

toLocationInGrid

public Location toLocationInGrid(int x,
                                 int y)
Returns the location (cell indices) of the cell where the point with given coordinates resides. Despite in a strict sense the pixels of the right and bottom border belongs to cells outside the visible cells, the location of the cooresponding visible border cell is returned. If the point is outside the grid, the closest location within the grid is returned.

Parameters:
x - x-coordinate (in pixels)
y - y-coordinate (in pixels)
Returns:
the location of the cell (cell indices) where the point resides

removeActor

public boolean removeActor(Actor actor)
Removes the given actor from the scene, so that act() is not called any more. The visiblity is turned off (spriteId = -1) and a registered mouse, mouse touch or key listener is removed.

Be aware that clicking the reset button or calling reset() will not bring the actor to life.
If you want to reuse the removed actor, you may add it again to the game grid (the sprite with id = 0 is shown). Any mouse, mouse touch or key listener must be registered again. Instead of removing the actor, call hide() to make him invisible and show() to display him again.

The buffered image resources will not be released until the actor reference runs out of scope. Because actors use a lot of heap space, you should be careful to remove actors and deassign their reference when they are no more used (e.g. moves out of the visible game grid).

Parameters:
actor - the actor to be removed
Returns:
true, if the specified actor is found and removed

removeAllActors

public int removeAllActors()
Removes all actors from the scene, so that act() is not called any more. The visiblity is turned off and any registered mouse, mouse touch or key listeners are disabled. Be aware that clicking the reset button or calling reset() will not bring the actors to life.

Returns:
the number of removed actors

removeActors

public int removeActors(java.lang.Class clazz)
Removes all actors from the specified class, so that act() is not called any more. The visiblity is turned off and any registered mouse, mouse touch or key listeners are disabled. Be aware that clicking the reset button or calling reset() will not bring the actor to life.

Parameters:
clazz - class of the actors to be removed, if null all actors are removed
Returns:
the number of removed actors

removeActorsAt

public int removeActorsAt(Location location,
                          java.lang.Class clazz)
Removes all actors from the specified class at the specified location, so that act() is not called any more. The visiblity is turned off and any registered mouse, mouse touch or key listeners are disabled. Be aware that clicking the reset button or calling reset() will not bring the actors to life.

Parameters:
location - the location of the cell
clazz - class of the actors to be removed, if null all actors are removed
Returns:
the number of removed actors

Returns:
the number of removed actors

actAll

public void actAll()
Invokes all actor's act() methods in the order of the scene and draws the new game situation. Corresponds to the next simulation act.

act

public void act()
Empty method called in every simulation cycle after all actor act() calls. Override to get your own notification.

Specified by:
act in interface GGActListener

setActOrder

public void setActOrder(java.lang.Class... classes)
Set the act order of objects in the scene. Act order is specified by class: objects of one class will always act before objects of some other class. The default act order is determined by the order the actor's classes are added to the game grid: last entry will act first. The act order of objects of the same class (called a scene)is given by the default act order: last entry will act first. This order within a class can be changed with setActorOnTop(), setSceneOrder(), shiftSceneOrder(), reverseSceneOrder().
Objects of classes listed first in the specified parameter list will act before any objects of classes listed later.

Objects of classes not listed will act after all objects whose classes have been specified.

Parameters:
classes - the classes in desired act order

setPaintOrder

public void setPaintOrder(java.lang.Class... classes)
Set the paint order of objects in the game grid. Paint order is specified by class: objects of one class will always be painted on top of objects of some other class. The default paint order is determined by the order the actor's classes are added to the game grid: last entry will be on top of first. The paint order of objects of the same class (called a scene) is given by the default paint order: last entry will be on top. This order can be changed with setActorOnTop(), setSceneOrder(), shiftSceneOrder, reverseSceneOrder().
Objects of classes listed first in the parameter list will appear on top of all objects of classes listed later.

Objects of classes not listed will appear below the objects whose classes have been specified.

At least one actor of the specified class has to be part of the scene, unless the paint order of this class is not modified.

Parameters:
classes - the classes in desired paint order

setActorOnTop

public void setActorOnTop(Actor actor)
Puts the given actor at last place in the corresponding scene list, in order to act first and to be drawn on top of other actors of the same class. If you want to change the paint order of actors in different actor classes, use GameGrid.setPaintOrder().

Parameters:
actor - the actor to put on top
See Also:
setPaintOrder(Class... classes)

setActorOnBottom

public void setActorOnBottom(Actor actor)
Puts the given actor at first place in the corresponding scene list, in order to act last and to be drawn on the bottom of other actors of the same class. If you want to change the paint order of actors in different actor classes, use GameGrid.setPaintOrder().

Parameters:
actor - the actor to put on the bottom
See Also:
setPaintOrder(Class... classes)

shiftSceneOrder

public Actor shiftSceneOrder(java.util.ArrayList<Actor> actors,
                             boolean forward)
Shifts (rolls) the actors of the given actor list in the corresponding scene list forward or backward. When shifting forward, the last element is reinserted at the beginning, when shifting backward, the first element is reinserted at the end. The scene list determines the act and paint order (act and paint order from first to last element. Last element is shown on top.) All actors must have the same type (determined by the first element of the list).

Parameters:
actors - a list of actors to shift
forward - if true, shifts to the right (forward); otherwise shifts to the left (backward)
Returns:
the actor put at top; null, if none of the actors is part of the scene list

reverseSceneOrder

public Actor reverseSceneOrder(java.util.ArrayList<Actor> actors)
Reverses the order of the given actor list in the corresponding scene list. The scene list determines the act and paint order (act and paint order from first to last element. Last element is shown on top.) All actors must have the same type (determined by the first element of the list).

Parameters:
actors - a list of actors to shift
Returns:
the actor put at top; null, if none of the actors is part of the scene list

setSceneOrder

public void setSceneOrder(java.util.ArrayList<Actor> actors)
Sets the act and paint order of the actors in the given list by rearraging their scene list to the order in the given list. (Actors will act and painted in the order of their scene list. Actors painted later will appear on top of actors painted before.) All actors must have the same type (determined by the first element of the list). Duplicated actors in the given list are ignored. To change the act or paint order of the actors class, use setActOrder() or setPaintOrder().

Parameters:
actors - a list of actors to rearrange

getPaintOrderList

public java.util.ArrayList<Actor> getPaintOrderList(java.lang.Class clazz)
Returns a list with actor references of the given class in the order they are painted. (Actors painted later will appear on top of actors painted before.)

Parameters:
clazz - the class of actors included in the list; if null, all actors are included
Returns:
a list of actor references

getPaintOrderList

public java.util.ArrayList<Actor> getPaintOrderList()
Returns a list with actor references in the order they are painted. (Actors painted later will appear on top of actors painted before.)

Returns:
a list of actor references

getTouchedActors

public java.util.ArrayList<Actor> getTouchedActors(java.lang.Class clazz)
Returns a list with actor references of all actors of the given class whose touched area (of type IMAGE, RECTANGLE or CIRCLE) intersects with the current mouse touch position.

Parameters:
clazz - the class of actors checked for a touch. If null, all actors are checked.
Returns:
a list of actor references. (Empty, if no actors are touched)

                              Location location,
                              double direction)

Parameters:

location - the location of the actor (cell indices, value copy)
direction - the direction (clockwise in degrees, 0 to east)

addActor

public void addActor(Actor actor,
                     Location location,
                     double direction)
Adds a new actor at given starting position with given moving direction to the scene. If the actor is already part of the scene, it must be removed from the scene before adding it again, because actors added to the scene should not be duplicated. The starting location and direction are saved and may be retrieved later. The actor reset notification is called in order an initialisation may be done.

More than one actor may be added at the same location and the location may be outside the visible game grid to hide the actor when added to the scene.

The image center is centered at the given location. For even image pixel width or height, the center is half pixel width to the left or resp. to the top. The default act and paint order is given by the order the actor are added, but all actors of the same class are bundled together. Actors added last will act and be painted first, but this default order may be modified. See setActOrder() and setPaintOrder() for more information.

Parameters:
actor - the actor to be added at the end of the scene list
location - the location of the actor (cell indices, value copy)
direction - the direction (clockwise in degrees, 0 to east)

addActor

public void addActor(Actor actor,
                     Location location)
Same as addActor(Actor actor, Location location, double direction) with direction = 0 (to east).

Parameters:
actor - the actor to be added at the end of the scene list
location - the location of the actor (cell indices, value copy)

addActor

public void addActor(Actor actor,
                     Location location,
                     Location.CompassDirection compassDir)
Same as addActor(Actor actor, Location location, double direction) with compass direction.

Parameters:
actor - the actor to be added at the end of the scene list
location - the location of the actor (cell indices)
compassDir - the compass direction

doReset

public void doReset()
If still running, calls doPause() and restores actors to their initializing state. The initializing state includes: starting location, starting direction, starting sprite id (set before adding actor to game grid), no horizontal or vertical mirroring, collision enabled, but collision type not changed. All actor's and the GameGrid's reset() methods are called. Then the game grid is refreshed.

Same as if the 'Reset' button is pressed. This method is not called automatically when the game grid is created.

doRun

public void doRun()
Starts the simulation cycling. Same as if the 'Run' button is pressed.

doPause

public void doPause()
Pause the simulation cycling. Same as if the 'Pause' button is pressed.

doStep

public void doStep()
Runs the the simulation loop once. Same as if the 'Step' button is pressed.

reset

public void reset()
Empty method called when the reset button is hit or doReset() is called. Override to get your own notification.

addTouchListener

public void addTouchListener(GGTouchListener listener,
                             int touchEventMask)
Adds a GGTouchListener to get notifications from touch events. More than one GGTouchListener may be registered. They are called in the order they are added. Be aware that if the notification method touchEvent() returns true, the event is "consumed" and no following GGTouchistener will be notified. Only the events defined as OR-combination in the specified mask are notified. If the touch was disabled, it is enabled now.

Parameters:
listener - the GGTouchListener to register
touchEventMask - an OR-combinaton of constants defined in class GGTouch

removeTouchListener

Removes the given touch listener from the list of registered touch listeners.

Parameters:
listener - the listener to remove
Returns:
true, if the listener is successfully removed; false, if the listener is not part of the touch listener list

                                                          boolean up)

getLineLocations

public java.util.ArrayList<Location> getLineLocations(Location loc1,
                                                      Location loc2,
                                                      boolean interjacent)
Returns a list of cell grid locations whose cell centers are exactly on the the line through the centers of loc1 and loc1. If interjacent is true, only locations between loc1 and loc2 are included. If the locations are the same and interjacent is false, the only location is included.

Parameters:
loc1 - the location of the first cell
loc2 - the location of the second cell
interjacent - if true, only location between loc1 and loc2 are included
Returns:
a list of cell whose centers are exactly (close within 10E-6) on the line through the two cell centers

requestLong

public long requestLong(java.lang.String title,
                        java.lang.String prompt,
                        long init)
Opens a modal input dialog with given title, prompt and initial value. The user input is validated and the dialog redrawn until a valid long is entered. If the cancel button is hit, the application terminates.

Parameters:
title - the title of the dialog box
prompt - the prompt in the dialog box
init - a proposal for the user input value
Returns:
the validated user input value

addNavigationListener

public void addNavigationListener(GGNavigationListener listener)
Registers a navigation listener to get notifications when the smartphones buttons are used (BACK, HOME, VOLUME_INCREASE and VOLUME_DECREASE). (Notifications for the HOME button are not supported by the Android API). The navigation option flag must be set in the GameGrid constructor, but the standard game grid navigation is disabled.

Parameters:
listener - the GGNavigationListener to register

addOrientationListener

public void addOrientationListener(GGOrientationListener listener)
Registers a orientation listener to get notifications when the smartphones changes orientation from LANDSCAPE to PORTRAIT or vice vera. No event occurs if the device is set to fixed screen orientation by calling setScreenOrientation() with parameter GGNavigationListener.PORTRAIT or GGNavigationListener.LANDSCAPE.

Parameters:
listener - the GGOrientationListener to register

setActEnabled

public void setActEnabled(boolean enable)
Enables/disables the simulation cycle momentarily. The navigation buttons are not modified.

Parameters:
enable - if true, a running simulation cycle is interrupted; otherwise a running simulation cycles is reenabled

isTileColliding

public boolean isTileColliding(Actor a,
                               Location location)
Checks if the given actor and the tile at the given tile location are colliding.

Parameters:
a - the actor to check for collision
location - the tile location
Returns:
true, if the actor and the tile are currently colliding; otherwise false

createTileMap

public GGTileMap createTileMap(int nbHorzTiles,
                               int nbVertTiles,
                               int tileWidth,
                               int tileHeight)
Creates a TileMap with the specified number of horizontal and vertical tiles. All tiles are invisible (images set to null).

Be aware that tileWidth and tileHeight are given in number of pixels, but the size of the tiles in pixel units is (tileWidth-1) x (tileHeight-1).

Parameters:
nbHorzTiles - the number of horizontal tiles
nbVertTiles - the number of vertical tiles
tileWidth - the width of each tile (in pixels)
tileHeight - the height of each tile (in pixels)

getTileMap

public GGTileMap getTileMap()
Returns the reference to the GGTileMap.

Returns:
a reference to the GGTileMap; null, if it is not yet created

enableNavigationNotifications

public void enableNavigationNotifications(boolean enabled)
Enables/disables navigation notifications (as toasts)

Parameters:
enabled - if true, the notifications are enabled; otherwise disabled (default)

createMediaPlayer

public android.media.MediaPlayer createMediaPlayer(java.lang.String audiopath)
Creates and prepares a MediaPlayer instance with given audio path name. When the method returns the audio stream is ready to play. This may take a while, so if you need an immediate start response, create the media player in a idle time before starting it. See class android.media.MediaPlayer for further information. Call release() so that resources used by the internal player engine associated with the MediaPlayer object are released.

Parameters:
audiopath - the path name of the audio file (must have one of the supported audio format). If no file name extension is used, the resource file is searched in the 'raw' resource folder. If an extension is given, the resource file is searched in the given relative path on the sdcard (the prefix '/sdcard'/ is added by the system)
Returns:
a MediaPlayer reference; null, if the sound resource fails to load

Opens the given raw resource (file in subdirectory res/raw).

Parameters:
filename - without extension
Returns:
an InputStream reference of the opened resource; null, if resource is not found

Parameters:

copyBinary

public static boolean copyBinary(java.io.InputStream in,
                                 java.lang.String outPath,
                                 boolean close)
Takes the given input stream and copies the data byte-by-byte to an output file.

Parameters:
in - the input stream where to take the data
outPath - the file path where to transfer the data (e.g. "/sdcard/out.mp3")
close - if true, closes the given input stream; otherwise let it open
Returns:
true, if successful; otherwise false

onCompletion

public void onCompletion(android.media.MediaPlayer mp)
Notification method called when the playback of a media file terminates. Calls MediaPlayer.release() to release all system resources. If overridden to get your own notification, call super.onCompletion() to release the resources.

Specified by:
onCompletion in interface android.media.MediaPlayer.OnCompletionListener
Parameters:
mp - the MediaPlayer that terminiates

                     int duration)

sendSMS

public void sendSMS(java.lang.String phoneNumber,
                    java.lang.String message)
Sends a SMS with given message to the given recipient. If the message is longer than the maximum SMS message size (160 characters), a multipart message is sended.
You must add the following line as second to last line in AndroidManifest.xml (the line before </manifest>):
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.SEND_SMS" />

Parameters:
phoneNumber - the phone number of the recipient
message - the SMS message to send

getVibrator

public android.os.Vibrator getVibrator()
Returns the vibrator reference for this context. You must add the following line as second to last line in AndroidManifest.xml (the line before </manifest>):
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.VIBRATE" />

Returns:
the current vibrator reference

setNbRotSprites

public void setNbRotSprites(int nbSprites)
Sets the new number of rotated sprite images in the internal sprite store (default 60). Must be set before the first rotatable actor is created, otherwise the current number is unchanged. If the number is too high, a VM memory overflow for big sprite images may occur. 360 / nbSprites (default 6 degrees) is the angle resolution for the actor direction.

Parameters:
nbSprites - the number of sprites images in the sprite store (1..360)

setZoomFactor

public void setZoomFactor(double zoomFactor)
Enables/disables the auto zoom facility and sets the zoom factor to the given value. The zoom factor is also set by GameGrid constructor parameters cellZoom and windowZoom. Auto zoom is applied to all images (sprites, background images, etc.) when images is loaded. Be aware that a certain image is only loaded once and stored in an internal store for further use. So if you change the zoom factor, the stored images are not effected. The zoom factor is calculated automatically when the CellZoom or WindowZoom parameters in the GameGrid constructor are used.

Parameters:
zoomFactor - the factor > 0 applied for the image scaling operation; if 1 (+-1E-3) no zoom transformation (auto zoom disabled, default value)

getZoomFactor

public double getZoomFactor()
Returns the current zoom factor (set by setZoomFactor() or constructor parameters).

Returns:
the current zoom factor (1: no zoom)

cellZoom

public static GameGrid.CellZoom cellZoom(int cellSize)
Returns a CellZoom reference to be used as constructor parameter for apps based on grids. When used, all loaded images are automatically zoomed with the zoom factor cellSize / currentCellSize

Parameters:
cellSize - the standard cell size with no zoom (zoom factor = 1)

windowZoom

public static GameGrid.WindowZoom windowZoom(int windowSize)
Returns a WindowZoom reference to be used as constructor parameter for apps based on pixels. When used, all loaded images are automatically zoomed with the zoom factor windowSize / currentWindowSize

Parameters:
windowSize - the standard window size with no zoom (zoom factor = 1)

public int toVirtual(int tReal)
Returns the virtual value (int)(tReal / zoomFactor) of a real coordinate.

Parameters:
tReal - the real coordinate
Returns:
the virtual coordinate
